comments.commentBody: Because Market Power and Market Share are fundamentally different concepts. Market Share is simply a reflection of revealed consumer preference. Market Power is more difficult to 'see', but we know that it requires barrier to entry. Amazon has not placed any barriers to entry, so it's hard to argue that it has 'market power'.
Asad K "Market Power...requires barrier to entry. Amazon has not placed any...."  why did you use this strange term, "barrier to entry" without saying what it means?  Entry of what into what?

ERP  " Their competitors shouldn't need the government (or the NYT) to do their work for them. If they can't compete, they should step aside for someone else who can..."  So you prefer monopolies?  That's what unregulated competition leads to.  That's why we had anti-trust laws. Which I guess you hate, as they are a means to maintain democracy.

What I would be most afraid of is that Amazon would realize its "goal of becoming the seller of everything to everyone."  It's quite obvious that it is using monopoly power to aggrandize itself.  Why is that not illegal?  Because we no longer enforce anti-trust laws?  (We don't, by the way, in many other instances.)

For me, this article is summed up in this sentence: "Not every expert is persuaded that the long-term benefits of handwriting are as significant as all that." This is one study, and people jumping onto it to make their point of "oh I was taught this way and I think better this way and my children have said that too" is just as anecdotal as this preliminary research. For some people, I have no doubt that writing is the best way for them to absorb and process information, especially children just learning their letters for the first time. For most people who grew up with computers, any loss of temporary memory is rectified by an ability to take more notes that are often clearer after lectures than handwritten notes. While the brain may not register the information in the same way, the ability to pull up the information later as you study is invaluable. Technology comes with trade-offs, and it is too soon to say whether handwriting can be safely eliminated about learning basic writing - and no school that I know of (as an education policy analyst) is planning on doing that. If we are getting into anecdotes, I spend my life writing long, detailed research papers and short, meticulously-worded emails, and I could not write - both physically and mentally - without using a word-processing software.

Please stop commenting that "see I knew cursive was necessary" so we can talk about the real meat of the article - the fact that more research in this area should be done.

The research makes a strong case for handwriting—but only the weakest case that it must be cursive rather than any of the other forms of handwriting.
The closest it came to a case for cursive was in noting that some stroke survivors lose the ability to read typefonts. Never mentioned: just asoften, the ability to read cursive is lost, but reading of type/print-writing is preserved.

The paper also ignored research that discomfited cursive's cheerleaders. It turns out (sources on request) that:

• legible cursive writing averages no faster than print-writing of equal or greater legibility

• cursive does NOT objectively improve the reading, spelling, or language of students who have dyslexia/dysgraphia

• the fastest, clearest handwriters are neither the “print”-writers nor the cursive writers. Highest speed and legibility are attained by those who join only some letters, not all of them—making the simplest joins, omitting the rest, using print-like shapes for letters whose printed and cursive shapes disagree.

Why—in the NY TIMES as elsewhere—do studies that are headlined as supporting cursive actually say something different when anyone looks up the actual research? Why, one-sidedly, does the science writer ignore research that can't be headlined as "cursive"?

Let's stop using the word education and start calling it what it is -- socialized child neglect! Of course I'm exaggerating to make a point, but isn't that really the direction we take when we disparage any skill, be it writing (which also includes numerals, necessary for performing math, not just letters), or shooting hoops, or designing a car. I took a drafting class. The professor taught us to make actual blueprints using pencil and ruler before AutoCad. The result? We picked up the program like we had always used it. Students who went straight to the computer we left in our dust, even if they had used it longer. The ends without the means is, well, meaningless.
